doc.repnme: Information costs, risks, and the regulation of insurance
doc.abstracts: Insurance regulations primarily aim to protect the interests of consumers and investors and to safeguard the soundness and solvency of insurance companies. Close regulation and supervision are justified by the high information costs associated with insurance products. These information costs arise from three main sources: (1) the complexity of contractual terms and conditions of coverage that put consumers at a considerable disadvantage against insurance companies and their agents; (2) the need to pool the insured with different risk characteristics into relatively homogeneous groups which can cause problems for both consumers and insurance companies; and (3) the difficulty of assessing the financial soundness of insurers. This Note explains how regulators address these problems.
